solution_line_template: If Mark bought {mark_cans} cans of milk, the number of times Jennifer added 6 cans for every {mark_per_jennifer} that Mark bought is {mark_cans}/{mark_per_jennifer} = <<{mark_cans}/{mark_per_jennifer}={times_jennifer_added}>>{times_jennifer_added} times.

The total number of additional cans she bought is {times_jennifer_added}*{jennifer_added_per_time} = <<{times_jennifer_added}*{jennifer_added_per_time}={total_additional_cans}>>{total_additional_cans} cans.

If she initially had {initial_jennifer_cans} cans, she went home with {initial_jennifer_cans}+{total_additional_cans} = <<{initial_jennifer_cans}+{total_additional_cans}={total_jennifer_cans}>>{total_jennifer_cans} cans of milk.
